title: Matteo Garrone
text:
Matteo Garrone (born 15 October 1968) is an <a href="Italians">Italian</a> filmmaker. Born in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, the son of a theatre critic, Nico Garrone and a photographer, in 1996 Garrone won the "Sacher d'Oro", an award sponsored by <a href="Nanni%20Moretti">Nanni Moretti</a>, with the short film "Silhouette", that became one of the three episodes that are on his first long feature, "Terra di Mezzo" in 1997. 
He won Best Director at the <a href="European%20Film%20Awards">European Film Awards</a> and at the <a href="David%20di%20Donatello%20Awards">David di Donatello Awards</a> for "<a href="Gomorrah%20%28film%29">Gomorrah</a>" (2008), among many other awards. His film "<a href="Reality%20%282012%20film%29">Reality</a>" (2012) competed in competition at the <a href="2012%20Cannes%20Film%20Festival">2012 Cannes Film Festival</a> and won the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20%28Cannes%20Film%20Festival%29">Grand Prix</a>.
His films "<a href="Tale%20of%20Tales%20%282015%20film%29">Tale of Tales</a>" (2015) and "<a href="Dogman%20%28film%29">Dogman</a>" (2018) were selected to compete for the <a href="Palme%20d%27Or">Palme d'Or</a> at the <a href="2015%20Cannes%20Film%20Festival">2015 Cannes Film Festival</a> and the <a href="2018%20Cannes%20Film%20Festival">2018 Cannes Film Festival</a> respectively. The <a href="Nastro%20d%27Argento">Nastro d'argento</a> awarded Garrone both <a href="Nastro%20d%27Argento%20for%20Best%20Producer">Best Producer</a> and <a href="Nastro%20d%27Argento%20for%20Best%20Director">Best Director</a> with "Dogman". He received the latter again for "<a href="Pinocchio%20%282019%20film%29">Pinocchio</a>" (2019).
